channel.title: Portfolios on Marissa Barlaz, PhD
channel.description: Recent content in Portfolios on Marissa Barlaz, PhD

item.title: Bayesian Analysis in R
item.description: What is Bayesian analysis? A simple Bayesian analysis Why use Bayesian analysis? How to run a Bayesian analysis in R Step 1: Data exploration Step 2: Define the model and priors Determining priors How to set priors in brms Step 3: Fit models to data Step 4: Check model convergence Step 5: Carry out inference Evaluate predictive performance of competing models Summarize and display posterior distributions Hypothesis testing Hypothesis testing using CrIs The packages I will be using for this workshop include:

item.title: Praat Functions in R
item.description: Function setup Check for packages Create files on computer Get data from files Utilizing the functions The aim of this document is to automate acoustic data acquisition in R without having to directly use Praat scripting. Rather, these functions will interact with Praat for you. You will need to segment files in Praat manually. Given the absolute directory to a folder, the functions will loop through a folder that has a set of .

item.title: Text Mining with R
item.description: #Setting up an API The first thing to do with R when getting ready to do Twitter mining is to set up your credentials. I won’t go through this process right now, but it is outlined here. You need to first become a Twitter developer and create an app. It only takes a few moments. There are a couple of different types of flows you can work with, depending on what your question is.

item.title: R Graphing Workshop
item.description: Data Introduction to ggplot Aesthetics Faceting Statistical Transformations Other Aspects of the graph Colors Wrapping up The aim of this workshop is to teach you the ins and outs of using the ggplot2 package in R. The materials for this workshop can be found here. A lot of the information in this workshop is based on workshops given at Harvard: https://dss.iq.harvard.edu/workshop-materials Please make good use of the following cheat sheet!

item.title: Data Processing with the Tidyverse
item.description: Data Manipulation with dplyr Filter Arrange Select Mutate group_by Summarise Separate Unite #Why the tidyverse? There are a few reasons to use R and the Tidyverse for data processing. Excel is opaque – if you make a change to a cell/row/column, unless you write down exactly what you did, you have no way of knowing how you processed your data. Using R and documenting your work in Rmarkdown will allow you to understand exactly what you are doing, which is helpful in future iterations of using the data.

item.title: ERP Data Analysis in R
item.description: Preprocessing Required packages Read in data Convert to long format, combine data frames Plotting time courses P600 and N400 calculations ANOVA k means clustering Plotting S125 - S115 S135 - S115 GAM topo plotting Difference plotting Making a movie Preprocessing Required packages library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching packages ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.0 ── ## ✓ ggplot2 3.3.2 ✓ purrr 0.3.4 ## ✓ tibble 3.0.3 ✓ dplyr 1.

item.title: Introduction to R and RMarkdown
item.description: R as a calculator Variables Functions Data Frames Subsetting RMarkdown Formatting Bullet Points #Welcome to R! You might be asking, why should I use R instead of another type of software? In addition to being able to do statistics (like in Minitab, SPSS, Stata, etc.), you can do high-level scripting, statistical programming, and exploratory data analysis in R. It is free and open-source, meaning there is a large community of contributors and users.

item.title: R Modeling Workshop
item.description: What is the point? Data Simple linear regression Moving beyond simple linear regression Interactions Categorical Predictors Predicting Values Binary Outcomes Polynomial Regression Mixed Effects Models The aim of this workshop is to teach you the basics of statistical models in R. The materials for this workshop can be found here. What is the point? When looking at data, we want to determine if there is a relationship between our independent and dependent variables.

item.title: Contrast coding in R
item.description: Data processing What is a contrast? Coding schemes Dummy coding Effects coding Contrast coding Sum coding Helmert coding Regular Helmert coding Reverse Helmert coding User-defined contrasts Post-hoc tests Dummy coding Sum coding Data processing For this tutorial, I am using my dissertation data. I am using one speaker’s data so we don’t have to account for individual differences, and I am only using the midpoint of the vowel.

item.title: GAM in R
item.description: Packages Data What is a generalized additive model? Running a GAM in R Fitting a basic GAM Visualizing GAM results Random effects Random intercepts Random slopes Random factor smooths Other topics to consider Packages The packages you will need for this workshop are as follows. I am also including the hex codes for a colorblind-friendly palette, which I use for my plots. I used the gganimate package to show my dissertation data (below), but this is not crucial for data processing/analysis.

item.title: Ordinal logistic regression in R
item.description: Packages What is ordinal logistic regression? Probabilities, odds, and odds ratios Set-up of the model Running an ordinal logistic regression in R Data Initial model Adding another term Including a continuous predictor Interactions Random effects The full model Packages The packages you will need for this workshop are as follows. I am also including the hex codes for a colorblind-friendly palette, which I use for my plots.

item.title: Eye Tracking Analysis
item.description: What is the visual world paradigm? How to process eye tracking data in R Data preparation VWPre method eyetrackingR method Data plotting VWPre eyetrackingR Data analysis Linear mixed effects regression Growth curve analysis Generalized additive modeling Conclusions and references What is the visual world paradigm? The basic set-up in a comprehension visual world experiment is simple: On each trial the participants hear an utterance while looking at an experimental display.

item.title: Regular Expressions in R
item.description: A brief introduction to the tidyverse Filter Arrange Select Mutate summarise and group_by A brief introduction to strings Regular expressions Practice The dataset I will use for this workshop is the set of lyrics to songs from the Broadway musical Les Mise'rables. The data looks like this: head(lesmis, 30) ## # A tibble: 30 x 7 ## track_title track_n line lyric element element_artist title ## <chr> <int> <int> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> ## 1 Prologue (Ft.

item.title: Vowel Normalization in R
item.description: What is vowel normalization? Types of vowel normalization Speaker intrinsic/vowel intrinsic/formant intrinsic Log transformations ERB Bark Mel Speaker intrinsic/vowel intrinsic/formant extrinsic Bark distance model Speaker intrinsic/vowel extrinsic/formant intrinsic Z-score/Lobanov normalization Individual log means (Nearey1) Centroids (Watt-Fabricius) Speaker intrinsic/vowel extrinsic/formant extrinsic Shared log-mean (Nearey2) Speaker extrinsic/vowel extrinsic/formant extrinsic ANAE method Which method is best? I will be using the following packages in this workshop.

item.title: Introduction to LaTeX
item.description: Introduction to LaTeX What is LaTeX? What’s so great about LaTeX? What’s not so great about LaTeX? Editors Basics of LaTeX Important symbols and commands The preamble Document classes Page formatting Packages Body Title page Sections Font styles Figures Tables Bibliographies Other possibilities with LaTeX Introduction to LaTeX What is LaTeX? LaTeX is a document preparation system, that is becoming the de-facto method in STEM fields, such as math, physics and computer science.

item.description: PraatR Pitch analysis rPraat Using apply to create .Pitch files PhonTools Pitch tracking Formant Tracking Comparison and plotting F0 Plotting Formants - PhonR and ggplot PhonR ggplot2 Spectrograms with PhonTools library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching packages ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.0 ── ## ✓ ggplot2 3.3.2 ✓ purrr 0.3.4 ## ✓ tibble 3.0.3 ✓ dplyr 1.0.2 ## ✓ tidyr 1.1.2 ✓ stringr 1.4.0 ## ✓ readr 1.

item.title: Phonetics Tools in R - Supplementary code
item.description: Data processing PraatR Dygraphs Create shorter examples from long audio Create dygraphs Getting information from two tiers Data processing library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching packages ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.0 ── ## ✓ ggplot2 3.3.2 ✓ purrr 0.3.4 ## ✓ tibble 3.0.3 ✓ dplyr 1.0.2 ## ✓ tidyr 1.1.2 ✓ stringr 1.4.0 ## ✓ readr 1.3.1 ✓ forcats 0.5.0 ## ── Conflicts ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── ## x dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ## x dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() library(PraatR) library(rPraat) library(phonR) library(dygraphs) library(phonTools) ## ## Attaching package: 'phonTools' ## The following object is masked from 'package:dplyr': ## ## slice library(audio) ## ## Attaching package: 'audio' ## The following object is masked from 'package:phonTools': ## ## play library(tuneR) ## ## Attaching package: 'tuneR' ## The following object is masked from 'package:audio': ## ## play ## The following objects are masked from 'package:phonTools': ## ## normalize, play library(gss) absdir = "/Users/marissabarlaz/Desktop/FemaleBP/" mydir = list.
